title: 'He does damage': 36-year-old Howie Kendrick has been Nationals' postseason hero
text:
CLOSE What I'm Hearing: From the nation's capital, Gabe Lacques details the Cardinals' confidence after going down 2-0 and how the Nationals are using a special six to hide their fatal flaw. USA TODAY

WASHINGTON – If there’s one constant for the Washington Nationals in the 2019 playoffs, it’s that when they need a clutch hit, Howie Kendrick is going to come through.

Their biggest hit in National League Division Series was Kendrick’s 10th-inning grand slam in the decisive fifth game against the Los Angeles Dodgers that propelled Washington into the NL Championship Series.

Then Monday night against the St. Louis Cardinals, Kendrick capped a four-run third inning with a two-out, two-run double into the gap in right-center.

“He’s built like a frickin’ cinderblock. He’s huge,” said third baseman Anthony Rendon. “He’s strong. So if he puts that barrel to it and stays behind the ball, you see it. He does damage.”

ROBLES: Nationals' young CF delivers in return from injury

ALCS: Gerrit Cole is back to haunt the Yankees

With three doubles and three RBI in four at-bats Monday night in an 8-1 win, Kendrick raised his batting average this postseason to .314. With runners in scoring position, he’s been even better: 5-for-10 (.500) with eight of his team-leading nine RBI.

"Howie has been setting the table the entire postseason,” first baseman Ryan Zimmerman said. “What a game by him tonight. I'm so happy for him after what he went through last year tearing his Achilles' and coming back.”

The injury last year limited him to only 40 games, but it also steeled his resolve to make the most of the second year of his two-year contract.

“Last year was bittersweet because I got off to a good start and ruptured my Achilles,” Kendrick said. “Having the ability to come back this year and be a part of this team and to be with the guys in the locker room, that was huge.”

Howie Kendrick reacts after his seventh-inning double in Game 3. (Photo: Patrick Semansky, AP)

At 36 years old, Kendrick led the team during the regular season with a .344 average that would easily have won the NL batting title if he had enough at-bats to qualify. But injuries have been a constant issue for him over the past few seasons.

“He’s worked so hard to get back from his Achilles injury and he’s worked tremendously on his swing with Kevin Long and it shows all the hard work pays off,” said outfielder Adam Eaton. “I’m so happy for him. I’m so happy to be his teammate and it’s a tremendous honor to be next to him.”

Kendrick gives a lot of the credit for his career resurgence to the job Long has done as the team’s hitting coach. He said the first time the two met, Kendrick asked what he could do to become a better hitter. He was surprised by the answer.

“He had a list, like he had wrote down on a pad of paper,” Kendrick recalled, gesturing to show that Long’s list was really … well, long.

“I wasn’t expecting it … He goes, 'all right. This is what I know about you. This is what you hit with this, this, and this. We got to work from there.' ”

When you'd expect him to the twilight of his 14-year career, Kendrick is having perhaps his best season ever.

“The way I look at it, is all those failures, and even now my failures still help me be successful. You appreciate it even more,” he said.

His teammates and his manager definitely appreciate him, especially since he’s helped them get so close to the World Series.

“He wants it, and the rest of his teammates feed off him,” Nationals skipper Dave Martinez said. “We’re all big fans of Howie … He’s been that quiet leader for us all year long.”
description: Washington's veteran infielder has come through with some of the biggest hits in the team's thrilling postseason run.
